instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesnâ€™t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that has green light, but no fanspin and no power.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> are missing.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is missing and <RESISTOR>R1461</RESISTOR> is OK
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> = 3.4V

<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> = 2,7V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL>=3.1V
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL>= 3.3V
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>=3.3V

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Fan will start very late on this model; not before CPU gets really hot.

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
Yes, I have 3.3 on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: I do have a drop pulse on  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> at same time.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>  is 0V but i have a small pulse when i triger  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Check the same for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> and all big coils.

Just in case, try starting in SMC bypass mode.
Be sure to have original 60/85W Magsafe 2 charger.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
I Have a pulse on  <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> but no pulse big coils  when triger  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, and on SMC bypass mode nothing happends.
With an original charger, the result is the same, no power

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> repeatedly and check for pulse at each coil.
If no voltage pulse at big coils, then check diode mode.
Start checking L7520.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Post <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> voltages; 23, 12, 13, 22, 29, 21.
Check for pulse at pin 4, when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.
Use surrounding components as test points, not directly chip pins.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

<CHIP>U7501</CHIP>:
23=12.59V
12=3.4V
13=1.9V
22=3.3V
29=5V
21=3.4V

I think that <SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_VREF2</SIGNAL> is low
 
I've got no pulse on pin 4 of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> when trigering  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
If <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulses, <SIGNAL>P5VS3_EN</SIGNAL> should pulse too.
If not, check <RESISTOR>R8175</RESISTOR>/79.

"I think that <SIGNAL>P5VP3V3_VREF2</SIGNAL> is low"
VREF2 means something, don't you think?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Well, i've never thinked about that, but now that you mentioned, i think that this means Reference Value. Is that correct?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: 2V internal reference, to be more precisely; so is good in your case.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Tks, for the explanation about VREF.

I do have a pulse on pin 4 of <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> when Trigering  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>. Sorry, I was trigering on the wrong place...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Then you should have pulse at L7520 too.
If not, there is a problem in <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> 5V area.
Check all resistors and traces.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Sorry, the same error. Trigering oat the wrong place.

I do have a pulse on L7520.
The only one that seams to don't pulse is L3095

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
That coil is not important.
So you get pulse on other big coils, including CPU ones?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,
in the morning I had a very small pulse on L7310 and L7320, but now, I checked again to confirm it and now, I don't get a pulse on them...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Can you catch any pulse at pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: I get pulse on both of them

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulsing?
Try new BIOS, just in case.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> has no pulse

Do you have a Clean BIOS for this board?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I've tried the new BIOS but with the same result.
No power and it has green light, when conected to the bench PSU it reaches 120 mA and imedatly drops to 15 mA

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> has no pulse"
Iy stays low, or high?
